an4.14:1.3: Exertion by restraint, exertion by abandoning, exertion by development, exertion by preservation.
an4.14:1.4: And what, monks, is exertion by restraint?
an4.14:1.5: Monks, here a monk, having seen a form with the eye, does not latch on to those primary or secondary characteristics
an4.14:1.6: in consequence of which one dwelling unrestrained with the eye-faculty would be flooded by greediness and disliking, and other vile, unwholesome mental states. One practices restraining it.  They guard the eye-faculty and pursue restraint regarding the eye-faculty.
an4.14:1.7: Having heard a sound with the ear ...
an4.14:1.8: Having smelled an odor with the nose ...
an4.14:1.9: Having tasted a flavor with the tongue ...
an4.14:1.10: Having felt a touch via the body ...
an4.14:1.11: Having cognized a thought with the mind, one does not latch on to those primary or secondary characteristics
an4.14:1.12: in consequence of which one dwelling unrestrained with the mind-faculty would be flooded by greediness and disliking, and other vile, unwholesome mental states. One practices restraining it.  They guard the mind-faculty and pursue restraint regarding the mind-faculty.
an4.14:1.13: Monks, this is called exertion by restraint.
an4.14:2.1: And what, monks, is exertion by abandoning?
an4.14:2.2: Monks, here a monk does not empower an arisen sensual thought, but abandons it, rejects it, makes an end of it, and annihilates it.
an4.14:2.3: So too with an arisen thought of disliking
an4.14:2.4: and an arisen thought of harming.
an4.14:2.5: They do not empower any other variously arisen vile and unwholesome thoughts, but abandon them, reject them, make an end of them, and annihilate them.
an4.14:2.6: Monks, this is called exertion by abandoning.
an4.14:3.1: And what, monks, is exertion by development?
an4.14:3.2: Monks, here a monk develops the ingredient of enlightenment mindfulness supported by unattached perspective, supported by dispassion, supported by recess, and maturing in release.
an4.14:3.3: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment exploration of phenomena ...
an4.14:3.4: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment energy ...
an4.14:3.5: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment joy ...
an4.14:3.6: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment tranquility ...
an4.14:3.7: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment collectedness ...
an4.14:3.8: They develop the ingredient of enlightenment levelheadedness supported by unattached perspective, supported by dispassion, supported by recess, and maturing in release.
an4.14:3.9: Monks, this is called exertion by development?
an4.14:4.1: And what, monks, is exertion by preservation?
an4.14:4.2: Monks, here a monk preserves a high quality object of collectedness—the perception of bones, the perception of a worm-filled corpse, the perception of a livid corpse, the perception of XXXXX
